questions.question_text: Which three CLI commands can you use to troubleshoot Layer 3 issues, if the issue is in neither the physical layer nor the link layer? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: AB is a valid response

Selected Answer: AB
A. Machine learning scan
B. Antivirus scan 

FortiGate Security 7.2 Study Guide (p.341):
"Like viruses, which use many methods to avoid detection, FortiGate uses many techniques to detect viruses. These detection techniques include:
• Antivirus scan
• Grayware scan
• Machine learning (AI) scan
If all antivirus features are enabled, FortiGate applies the following scanning order: antivirus scan, followed by grayware scan, followed by AI scan."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Answer are A and B
FortiGate Security 7.2 Study Guide page 341

Selected Answer: AB
The answer are A and B

Selected Answer: AB
Security 7.2 Antivirus page 341.

questions.question_text: What are two scanning techniques supported by FortiGate? (Choose two.)

Refer to the exhibit.

The exhibit shows a diagram of a FortiGate device connected to the network and the firewall policy and IP pool configuration on the FortiGate device.

Two PCs, PC1 and PC2, are connected behind FortiGate and can access the internet successfully. However, when the administrator adds a third PC to the network (PC3), the PC cannot connect to the internet.

//IMG//


Based on the information shown in the exhibit, which three configuration changes should the administrator make to fix the connectivity issue for PC3? (Choose three.)

choices.C: In the firewall policy configuration, disable ippool.
choices.D: In the IP pool configuration, set endip to 192.2.0.12.
choices.B: Configure 192.2.0.12/24 as the secondary IP address on port1.
choices.A: In the IP pool configuration, set type to overload.
choices.E: Configure another firewall policy that matches only the address of PC3 as source, and then place the policy on top of the list.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
I don't understand why E wouldn't work.

comments.content:
Hello @Lionel_P37
I believe that it is not a matter of creating another policy, but of solving the existing one. my answers: A,C,D
There is no info that this new rule has NAT enabled. Disable IPPOOL will use default NAT overload on the interface

discussion.content: ACD is the ideal response

Selected Answer: ACD
ACD it is.

D: If we disable Ippool via cli, the default will be overload. E: we create a new firewall policy but don't say anything about enable NAT, so this will fail.

comments.content: I mean C disable ippool, A and D

discussion.content: D only will work by iteself, dunno why we have to select three things

choices.A: Traffic is blocked because Action is set to DENY in the firewall policy.
choices.D: Log severity is set to error on FortiGate.
choices.B: Traffic belongs to the root VDOM.

discussion.content:
B. VDOM=root
C. Security=UTM

D. Log severity is set to error on FortiGate. obviously wrong
B. Traffic belongs to the root VDOM. correct (vd="root")
A. Traffic is blocked because Action is set to DENY in the firewall policy. wrong (msg="URL belongs to a DENIED CATEGORY in policy" It's meaning traffic blocked with "Security Profiles" but Action is allow int the firewall policy)
C. This is a security log. correct (type="utm")

Selected Answer: BC
B. Correct ("vd=root")
C. Correct ("type="utm")

Selected Answer: AC
A: action=blocked; msg = "URL belongs to a dnied categoy in policy" it's the same example of te FortiGate Security pg: 178
C: Security: type=UTM

C. Security log, log type = utm

A is not correct, because the log does not state that the firewall policy drops the packet. The log states it drop the packet because the web filter profile blocks it. Profile is not the firewall policy.

questions.question_text: Which two settings can be separately configured per VDOM on a FortiGate device? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:

C and D.

*NGFW mode (profile-based, policy-based)
